4. Occasions and Occasional Causation

We end with a brief look at what “ occasional causes” are
and how occasionalists understand “occasional
 causation.”[35]
 As we saw at the beginning of this entry, an occasionalist is someone
who, within a relevant domain, denies that creaturely causes are
genuine causes and holds that the unique genuine cause is God. This
denial of the causal efficacy of creatures, however, is consistent
with the recognition that some creaturely events and their types stand
in peculiar relations, noteworthy enough to deserve a special status
in the causal story of the world. Most prominent, particularly to
those interested in causation, are the robust regularities found in
the world, the very regularities that initiated our interest in causal
connections in the first place. These regularities are of interest to
the occasionalist as well, and it is for these regularities that the
occasionalist employs the notion of occasional causes. Here is how
Malebranche describes them: 

A natural cause is therefore not a real and true cause but only an
occasional cause, which determines the Author of nature to act in such
and such a manner in such and such a situation.(Search 448)


An occasional cause here is described as determining God “to act
in such and such a manner in such and such a situation.” The
central idea is that when an event of a certain type occurs, a
distinct event of a different type is brought about by divine
volition, such that a regular, law-like relation holds between two
types of events, each exemplified by the occasional cause and its
effect respectively. A common misunderstanding about occasionalism is
that if it is divine causality that anchors what occurs in the world,
such grounding of natural events will render their occurrences rather
irregular and haphazard. Perhaps it is the unpredictability of our own
volitional activity that precipitates this assumption that volitions
do not provide stable foundations for regularity. As we seen above,
however, occasionalists accept the regularity of natural events as
much as any realist about creaturely powers. The link that allows
occasionalists to endorse regularity while grounding such regularity
in divine volitions is their view that the divine volitions in
question have a stable, law-like structure, thus being general in
character. Here again is Malebranche:

God acts by general volition, when he acts in consequence of general
laws that he has established. For example, I say that God acts in me
by general volitions when he makes me feel pain when I am pricked [by
a pin], because, in consequence of the general and efficacious laws of
the union of soul and body that he has established, he makes me suffer
pain when my body is ill-disposed. I say, on the contrary, that God
acts by particular volitions when the efficacy of his will is not
determined by some general law to produce some effect― thus,
supposing that a body begins to move without being pushed by another,
or without changes in the will of some mind, or without some other
creature who determines the efficacy of some general law; I say that
God would move this body by a particular volition. (OCM V
147–48 /TNG 195)


When my body is injured, I subsequently feel pain. This pain,
according to Malebranche, is due to the “general and efficacious
law of the union of soul and body” that God has established,
and, thus, this injury is the occasional cause of the pain I feel.
Occasional causes, as noted earlier, are just those events of a
certain type on the occurrence of which God wills to be bring about an
instance of distinct, yet commonly conjoined, event type, such that
these two types of events are naturally correlated with robust
regularity. In fact, on the occasionalist scheme almost every event
that occurs in our world will turn out to be both an occasional cause
and effect in that it will be part of the vast network of regularities
that we observe. That is, any given effect that follows from an
occasional cause will, in turn, most likely be the occasional cause
for the following, subsequent effect. Thus, even on the occasionalist
picture, there are hardly any events that fail to be part of this
network of causal regularities, and such regularity is possible
because the overwhelming majority of events in the world are guided by
God’s general volitions, which are determined by general laws that
have been established by God. Note that this last
qualification—that the general laws themselves are established
by God—marks a critical difference between an occasionalist like
Malebranche and an Aristotelian essentialist about creaturely causal
powers. For the latter holds that certain effects follow necessarily
from the creature’s causal essence, while Malebranche rejects such
causal essences and denies any such necessary connection that holds
directly between a creaturely cause and
 effect.[36]

What events are exceptions and do not fall under general volitions?
These are what the occasionalists typically identify as miraculous
events, which, for Malebranche, would be those cases wherein God acts
by particular volitions. If an event occurs without its typical
preceding occasion and in violation of the general law known to us,
then such an event we are able to judge as occurring due to God
exercising his particular volition. Returning to Malebranche’s
own example, when “a body begins to move without being pushed by
another, or without changes in the will of some mind,” here God
can be said to move this body by a particular volition. However, even
in such instances, it is important to note that we should not think
that God is rejecting or overpowering some built-in essences within
the creature and conjoining some event inherently foreign to them. In
fact, as we have seen, one motivation behind the occasionalist project
was to avoid this picture of God having to act against natural
tendencies in miraculous cases, a picture that occasionalist charged
the Aristotelian essentialists to be committed to. For the
occasionalists, the general laws themselves are established by God
just as the particular volitions are exercised by God, hence there is
no struggle or conflict between divine volition and the results of
divine creation in either case. There is no need for God to overpower
his creation in cases of miraculous activity. Thus, on this
understanding of occasional causes, we can see that any occasion in
principle could be the antecedent event in God’s exercise of a
particular volition, resulting in a miracle, and any antecedent event
in actual miraculous events could have been conjoined to a general
volition. Creaturely states are at most occasions in that they are
devoid of causal natures or essences. 

Given this understanding of occasional causation, occasionalism, as we
noted in the beginning, can be understood as a metaphysics of
causation that promotes a more discriminating attitude toward what are
typically taken to be causal interactions operative in this world. The
occasionalist resists a blanket, univocal understanding of these
apparent causal interactions, and argues that we distinguish two types
of relations in the world, that of genuine causation and that of
occasional causation, wherein the latter relations are ultimately and
fundamentally grounded in the former.
